intro: Amphicarpaea elliotii, commonly known as Elliot's false flax, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Polygonaceae family and is characterized by its upright, branching stems and small, greenish-white flowers. The plant produces two types of fruits: one above ground and one below ground, a unique adaptation known as amphicarpy. It thrives in moist, sandy soils and is often found in wetlands and along streambanks. Its ecological importance includes providing habitat and food for various invertebrates and small vertebrates.
